DOC.brief_summary: Central venous catheters are needed in the critical care setting to administer drugs. Three sites are available to gain vascular access: subclavian, internal jugular and femoral. Each site has complications, but there is no randomized controlled study which compared the 3 sites. The investigators hypothesis is that subclavian catheterization reduces the risk of major complications compared to internal jugular or femoral.
DOC.criteria: Patient admitted in the Intensive Care Unit Requiring Central Venous Catheterization Patients with only one site available
